DataElement.preferredName: Subject Activity Group Plan Study Activity Blinded Description ISO21090.ST.v1.0
DataElement.preferredDefinition: A collection of activities that are intended to occur or start for the same study subject at a specific point in the context of a particular study. EXAMPLE(S): (1) Clinic visit during which a physical exam, a blood test, and a substance administration occur (2) Telephone contact during which temperature, blood pressure and adverse events are reported (3) Recording multiple observation results in a diary (4) A treatment strategy that consists of drug administrations with rules for modifying doses OTHER NAME(S): visit, time point, study segment, course, treatment strategy, period, cycle The textual representation of the planned activity from the point of view of a blinded participant (study subject or study investigator). EXAMPLE(S): (1) During the second treatment epoch of a study, Arms A and B are still blinded and Arm C is no longer blinded. So, Arm A and B must have identical blindedDescriptions. (2) In a study with 3 arms, Arm 1: standard vaccine given in three shots at 2 months, 5 months, and 12 months of age; Arm 2: new vaccine given in three shots at 2 months, 5 months, and 12 months of age; Arm 3: new vaccine given in two shots at 2 months and 5 months of age. Subjects assigned to the third arm are unblinded at some point during 5 months and 12 months. By the time of the Third Shot Epoch, the "Arm 3/Third Shot" activity can be called by this, its unblinded name. However, the "Arm 1/Third Shot" and "Arm2/Third Shot" activities still need blinded names. Both these activities would have the blinded name (something like) "3-shot Arm/Third Shot".

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Subject Activity Group Plan Study Activity Blinded Description
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Some matter, situation, or event that is thought about, written about, or discussed.:An active process; excludes processes and mechanisms which fulfill biological functions.:Any number of entities (members) considered as a unit.:To devise, contrive, or form in design.:A detailed examination, analysis, or critical inspection of a subject designed to discover facts about it.:An active process; excludes processes and mechanisms which fulfill biological functions._A characteristic of experiment design in which one or more groups involved (receiving, administering, or evaluating intervention) are unaware of which intervention any particular subject is receiving.:A written or verbal account, representation, statement, or explanation of something.
